TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national who was born in DATE and currently lives in GPE ( GPE and GPE ) . The respondent Government were represented by PERSON , their Agent .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant married a NORP national , PERSON PERSON . The marriage was celebrated and registered at ORG ( Standesamt Bonn II ) in GPE , which delivered a marriage certificate ( PERSON ) to the couple the same day . In the marriage certificate , the applicant was given her husband ’s surname “ PERSON ” .

In DATE the applicant asked ORG of the NORP ORG ( GPE ministrijas GPE un migrācijas lietu pārvalde –“the PERSON and Migration Service ” ) to replace her former NORP passport that had been issued in her maiden name with a new passport in her married name . She made an express request for her new surname to be retranscribed correctly , without any amendment .

On DATE the Nationality and Migration Service issued the applicant with a new NORP passport . However , on page CARDINAL , the main page containing all the passport holder ’s basic details , her surname appeared as “ Mencena ” , not “ GPE . Officials at ORG explained to the applicant that the changes in the written form of her surname had been made on the basis of Regulation no . CARDINAL on the transcription and identification of forenames and surnames in documents , which required all surnames and forenames to be reproduced “ in accordance with the spelling rules of the NORP literary language ” and “ as near as possible to their pronunciation in their original language ” . Consequently , the affricative consonant “ tz ” was replaced by the letter “ c ” , which is pronounced [ ts ] in NORP and therefore has the same phonetic value . Likewise , the inflectional ending “ -a ” was added to the applicant ’s surname , denoting the feminine nominative singular . However , in the section entitled “ Special remarks ” ( “ PERSON atzīmes ” ) on page CARDINAL of the passport , ORG affixed a special stamp certifying that the original form ( oriģinālforma ) of the surname was “ GPE ” .

After trying in vain to persuade the officials at ORG who had issued her with the passport to rectify the written form of her surname , the applicant lodged an internal appeal with the departmental head . She argued among other things that the phonetic transcription and grammatical adaptation of her surname had violated her right to respect for her family life , as guaranteed by LAW . On an unspecified date , the departmental head dismissed her appeal on the grounds that page CARDINAL of the passport provided the original version of the surname “ GPE in any event and that there had therefore been no alteration to the surname .

The applicant issued proceedings against ORG in ORG of GPE , which dismissed her claim in a judgment of DATE . After referring to an opinion of the linguistic consultations department of ORG valodas institūta NORP valodas konsultāciju dienests ) dated DATE , which stated that the transcription of the NORP name “ PERSON ” into NORP had to be “ Mencena ” for a woman , ORG found that the applicant ’s surname had been transcribed in accordance with the applicable regulations , namely Regulation no . CARDINAL on the passports of NORP citizens , and Regulation no . CARDINAL on the transcription and identification of forenames and surnames in documents . It also pointed out that persons finding themselves in that situation could always have the original form of their surname entered in the section of the passport entitled “ Special remarks ” if they so wished .

The applicant appealed against that judgment to ORG , arguing , inter alia , that ORG had misconstrued the domestic legislation . In her appeal , the applicant criticised the very principle of “ LOC ” of the written form of foreign surnames and forenames . In her submission , the CARDINAL sets of regulations cited in the impugned judgment violated the right to respect for private life guaranteed by LAW . The applicant also pointed out that neither LAW nor the relevant regulations required any grammatical or spelling changes to foreign trademarks or commercial undertakings . That being so , it was questionable whether such a practice with regard to names was either necessary or proportionate . Lastly , the applicant said that , owing to the change in the written form of her surname , she and her husband now had CARDINAL different surnames in their identity papers , which made their identification as members of the same family more difficult .

In a judgment of DATE , ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . After noting that ORG had fully complied with the applicable law and regulations , it accepted that the situation complained of could be regarded as interference with the right guaranteed by LAW . However , it considered that the interference , which was intended to protect the NORP language , was consistent with the second paragraph of that provision . With regard to the applicant ’s submission that different rules applied to trademarks and company names , ORG considered that it had no bearing on the case before it , since people ’s names fell into a completely different category and were governed by special rules .

The applicant appealed on points of law to ORG of ORG , arguing , inter alia , that the protection of the NORP language could not be a legitimate aim for which restrictions were permitted by LAW . In a judgment of DATE , ORG dismissed her appeal , holding that , since the original form of the surname “ PERSON ” appeared on page CARDINAL of her passport , there had been no violation of her right to respect for her private life .

After amendments to LAW ( PERSON tiesa ) had come into force , the applicant lodged an appeal ( konstitucionālā sūdzība ) with that court seeking a declaration that section CARDINAL of LAW no . CARDINAL on the transcription and identification of forenames and surnames were unconstitutional . She submitted that the impugned provisions contravened Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW .
ORG decided the issue in a judgment of DATE ( case no . DATE ) . After acknowledging that surnames came within the scope of private life , it stated :

( CARDINAL ) ... ORG accepts the applicant ’s argument that the ‘ Latvianisation’ [ latviskošana ] of her surname affected her emotionally . The fact that her surname is not spelt in the same way as her husband ’s is a source of unpleasantness and social inconvenience . It makes DATE life more complicated , as she has to give additional explanations on her relationship with her partner . While the misunderstandings are eventually cleared up , it all takes time .
... CARDINAL of the main functions ... of the forename and surname is to make it possible to identify people and to determine the relationship of the person concerned with his or her family .

In view of the applicant ’s psychological attitude to the transcribed surname and the complications it entails in DATE life which , especially abroad , can be seen in the difficulty which others have in determining her relationship with her family , and since the stability of the surname affects not only the individual ’s private life but also the interests of society , the provision requiring foreign surnames in passports issued in GPE to be transcribed in accordance with the traditions of the NORP language and its linguistic rules must be considered to constitute interference in private life .
( CARDINAL ) ... [ The ] interference in the applicant ’s private life is in accordance with the law , as it has been provided for by regulations issued by the ORG .

( CARDINAL ) The applicant ’s argument that the NORP transcription of her surname does not pursue any of the aforementioned legitimate aims is without basis . Names are one of the features of language and the issue of the rules applicable thereto affects the entire system of language . It can be seen from the case file that the applicant in fact criticises the very principle of transcribing foreign surnames , which is a characteristic of the NORP language . Consequently , in order to determine whether the interference ... pursues a legitimate aim , it is necessary to examine the role of the NORP language in GPE .

By declaring that the official language of GPE is NORP , LAW it constitutional status . The constitutional status of the official language reinforces the legal basis for the use of NORP in documents issued by GPE . Regard being had to the fact that a NORP citizen ’s passport is an official document that not only identifies the person concerned , but also attests to a permanent legal link between the individual and the ORG , that person ’s surname and forename must be written in the official language .

... ORG agrees with the opinion of the expert ... that the surname is used not just by the person so named , but also by society . Consequently , surnames must be regulated ... for the convenience of members of society .

Owing to historical factors , in particular the fact that the proportion of NORP [ of origin ] on the national territory has diminished during the course of DATE , the NORP nation represents only a minority in some large towns , including GPE ... , and the NORP language has only recently recovered its status as the official language . The need to protect the official language and to consolidate its use is , therefore , closely linked to the democratic regime of ORG .

Regard being had to the fact that , ... in the context of globalisation , GPE is the only place in the world where the existence and development of the NORP language and , by the same token , the NORP nation , can be guaranteed , a restriction or limitation on the use of [ this ] language ... on the national territory constitutes a threat to the democratic regime of the ORG .

[ In a recent judgment , ] ORG also came to the conclusion that the official language helps to preserve national identity , unites the nation , and serves to express national sovereignty and the indivisibility of the ORG ...

That being so , the purpose of the interference in the applicant ’s private life was to protect the right of other residents of GPE to use the NORP language freely throughout the national territory and to protect the democratic regime of the ORG . Accordingly , the interference ... pursued legitimate aims .
( CARDINAL ) ... [ It ] is necessary to examine whether the interference [ in issue ] was proportionate to the legitimate aims [ it pursued ] .

( CARDINAL ) ... ORG has no doubt that the written form of names in documents has a direct bearing on the other spheres in which the language is used , as they are closely connected . If the written form of foreign names in documents were only permitted in their original form , it would be coherent and logical for their use [ in this form ] to spread progressively , because names are used in different texts . It is impossible to isolate the written form of foreign names in identity papers from [ their written form in other types of document ] . That would seriously threaten the quality of the NORP language and , therefore , the function of [ this ] language in society ...

The evidence in the case file shows that the [ impugned ] interference has not prevented the applicant ... from exercising other rights she possesses , such as to cross her and other States’ borders , to vote in elections and to receive mail . The inconvenience an individual might suffer in his or her DATE life does not constitute a sufficient ground for not applying rules that are the consequence of the language ’s official status .

ORG considers that the damage to the functioning of the NORP language as a single system that would result from writing foreign names in their original form only would outweigh the inconvenience individuals might suffer as a result of using a passport issued in a surname transcribed in accordance with the traditions of the NORP language .
In these circumstances , the functioning of the NORP language as a single system ... constitutes a social necessity , not a whim of the ORG authorities .

In some cases , transcription of the surname may make it more difficult to identify a person or to determine his or her relationship with his or her family ( partner ) . However , the interests in protecting NORP as the official language and , therefore , in protecting the democratic ORG system , justify [ this interference ] .

( CARDINAL ) The applicant ’s allegation that the surname that she acquired by marriage has been transformed is unfounded . The transcription [ atveide ] of a name does not constitute its translation into NORP ( it is not the ORG of the noun [ as such ] ) , but its adaptation to the grammatical particularities of the NORP language .

There are a large number of systems of writing in the world , which are widely used , and the differences between them make it objectively impossible when passing from CARDINAL system to another to preserve the original form . Due to the difference between alphabets , absolute conformity to the original is impossible even between languages using NORP characters . In NORP , since the beginnings of written language , the settled practice has been to transcribe foreign names according to their pronunciation in the original language , not their written form . Regulation no . CARDINAL translates this principle governing the written form of foreign names , which is a characteristic of the NORP language , into a legal rule ...

Both the [ Official ] LAW no . CARDINAL refer to rules of literary language . ... [ At ] the base of NORP grammar are declensions . The word endings indicate the gender and number of ordinary and proper nouns and the function of the word in the sentence . The declinable word - ending of a name indicates the gender of the bearer of the name . In many NORP languages ( such as LANGUAGE , NORP and NORP ) , either names have no grammatical gender or no distinction is made in the form of male and female surnames . Consequently , in these languages , foreign names can be incorporated into a sentence in their original form without destroying the grammatical system of the language . However , in NORP , a foreign surname can not be included in a sentence ... unless it is written in the way it is pronounced and has an ending . Consequently , the traditions governing the written form of foreign names are based on the grammatical particularities of the NORP language .

ORG can not therefore accept the applicant ’s submission that the damage to her rights is greater than the benefit to the ORG . With a limitation of this sort on the private life of the individual , the ORG enhances the stability of the NORP language system . Compliance with the codified traditional rules ... in all spheres of use and writing of names , including documents , plays an integral role in the concrete historical circumstances of the ORG in establishing the status of the official language . ...

( CARDINAL ) In order to reduce the inconvenience caused by the transcription of a person ’s name as far as possible , the [ Official ] LAW provides : ‘ [ When ] the person concerned ... so wishes and is able to produce documentary evidence [ of it ] , the original form of the foreign surname shall be indicated in the passport , in addition to his or her forename and surname as transcribed ... ’

The meaning of the expression ‘ in addition to’ [ papildus ] has been defined by the ORG in its Regulation no . CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL of this regulation provides : ‘ ... when the person concerned so wishes , the original form of his or her surname and forename shall be entered in the section “ Special remarks ” , in accordance with the documentary evidence [ supplied ] ... ’ ...

However , section CARDINAL of Directive no . DATE issued by the head of ORG ... provides for the original form to be entered only on page CARDINAL of the passport , that is to say after the other [ relevant personal ] details . ...

Regard being had to the fact that , by choosing the place where the original form of the surname ... should be entered , the ORG has not done all in its power to ensure that the transcription of the surname causes the least harm to the individual , the provision of Regulation no . CARDINAL ... , which provides that the original form ... is to be entered in the field ‘ GPE , constitutes disproportionate interference with private life ... and is therefore incompatible with LAW and section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW . ”

On the basis of this reasoning , ORG found section CARDINAL of LAW , which establishes the general principle that foreign surnames are to be transcribed phonetically and adapted grammatically , consistent with LAW . However , it declared the regulation requiring the original form of the surname to be indicated on page CARDINAL of the passport and not in a more visible location nearer the front to be unconstitutional , having regard to the fact that the main page of the passport was page CARDINAL . ORG stated in particular that these provisions , including LAW no . DATE , would cease to be effective and would lapse on DATE .

LAW ( PERSON ) provides : “ The NORP language is the official language in GPE . ” LAW guarantees “ inviolability of private life , the home and correspondence ” . However , LAW permits restrictions on the exercise of that right in order to “ protect the rights of others , the democratic structure of the ORG , public safety , welfare and morals ” .

Section CARDINAL of the Forenames and Surnames ( Written Form in Documents ) Act of DATE ( NORP par vārdu un uzvārdu rakstību dokumentos ) , which has been repealed , laid down that forenames and surnames of foreign origin were to be written as they were pronounced in NORP , with the adjunction of the appropriate inflectional ending .
Section CARDINAL of the former LAW ( Valodu likums ) , which was in force until DATE , provided :
“ NORP names shall be used in accordance with NORP traditions and the rules of the language .
Names of foreign origin shall be transcribed and used in NORP in accordance with the rules of transcription [ atveide ] applicable to names of foreign origin . ”
Section CARDINAL of the new LAW ( NORP valodas likums ) , which was passed on DATE and came into force on DATE , reads as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Names shall be transcribed in accordance with the traditions of the NORP language and the rules applicable to literary language , regard being had to the provisions of subsection ( CARDINAL ) of this section .

( CARDINAL ) The historical form of the family surname of the person concerned or , if he or she ... so wishes and is able to adduce documentary evidence [ of it ] , the original form of the foreign surname transliterated into the NORP alphabet , shall be entered in the passport and birth certificate in addition to his or her forename and surname transcribed in accordance with the current forms of the NORP language .
( CARDINAL ) Regulations shall govern the spelling and identification of forenames and surnames and the spelling and use of foreign names in the NORP language . ”

The relevant parts of Regulation no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE on the transcription and identification of forenames and surnames in documents ( GPE par vārdu un uzvārdu rakstību un identifikāciju dokumentos ) provide :

“ ... In all documents drafted in the official language , the person ’s name and surname shall be written in accordance with the spelling rules of the NORP literary language , using only the letters of the alphabet of the NORP literary language . All forenames and surnames ( with the exception of indeclinable forenames and surnames ) must have an ending that conforms to the rules governing nouns and adjectives in the NORP language . The names of people of the female sex must have the ending of the feminine gender . The forenames and surnames of foreign origin ending in o , -ā , ē , i , ī , -u , -ū in the nominative singular are indeclinable in NORP . ”

“ Irrespective of their etymology in NORP , forenames and surnames of foreign origin must be written so as to be as close as possible to their pronunciation in the language of origin in accordance with the rules for transcribing foreign names . Depending on the sex of the person concerned , a masculine or feminine gender ending shall be added to forenames and surnames of foreign origin , unless the forenames or surnames are indeclinable . ”

“ If the form of the forename or surname entered in the documents delivered in the NORP language is liable to make the holder ’s identification more difficult , the original form of the forename or surname may be indicated in the passport in accordance with Regulation ... no . CARDINAL on the passports of NORP citizens ... If the language of origin does not use NORP characters , such indication will be through transliteration into the NORP alphabet . ”

“ The record of a person ’s forename or surname in a document shall be legally identical to that contained in the birth certificate ( or other document ) if both records are wholly identical or the only differences between them are as follows :
( CARDINAL ) Each of the records is consistent with the grammatical or spelling rules of the NORP language at different historical periods , [ that is to say ] :
( CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL ) an ending has been added to the forename or the surname in CARDINAL document , but not in the other ;
( DATE ) NORP the ending of the forename or surname in each document is of a different declension ;
( CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL ) the forename or surname in each document is spelt differently ;
( CARDINAL ) the forename and surname are written in a foreign language in CARDINAL document and in NORP in another ;
( CARDINAL ) the forename or surname in each document is written using different rules for transcribing names of foreign origin . ”

Regulation no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE on the transcription and identification of forenames and surnames ( GPE par vārdu un uzvārdu rakstību un identifikāciju ) largely repeats the provisions of the preceding regulation . The other relevant provisions of this regulation are as follows :
“ If the person wishes to keep ... the historical form or original form of his or her surname and submits documents attesting to such form :

( CARDINAL ) the [ competent ] authorities shall indicate at a set point in the documents the historical form , original form or transliterated form of the person ’s surname in the NORP alphabet ( [ that is to say ] reproduced , letter by letter , from another alphabet ) ;
“ The form of the surname ... written in NORP shall be legally identical to the original form of the surname , the historical [ form ] or the form transliterated into LANGUAGE characters . ”
“ In copies and extracts , the forename and the surname shall preserve their original written form . ”

“ If the transcription of a person ’s forename or surname is damaging to his or her vital interests , he or she may apply to ORG ( NORP valodas centrs ) with a request for the name to be transcribed into NORP in a form that is less damaging to his or her interests . ORG opinion on the manner in which the person ’s forename and surname must be written in the official language shall be binding on the [ competent ] authorities . ”

In GPE the passport is the principal identity document of NORP nationals . LAW no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE on passports of NORP citizens ( GPE par Latvijas pilsoņu pasēm ) , which was in force until DATE , provided that if a person wished to have the original written form of his or her forename and surname entered in his or her passport , it was to be entered in the section of the passport headed “ Special remarks ” ( “ LOC atzīme ” ) . LAW no . DATE issued by the head of ORG ( the statutory predecessor to ORG ) states that the original written form must appear on a special stamp affixed to page CARDINAL of the passport .

On DATE , following ORG judgment cited above , ORG no . CARDINAL on the transcription and use of names of foreign origin in the NORP language ( GPE par citvalodu personvārdu rakstību un lietošanu latviešu valodā ) , meticulously codifying the rules for the transcription of foreign names . The relevant paragraphs of the regulation read as follows :
“ In NORP , feminine names , whether of NORP or foreign origin , shall be formed and used with the respective feminine gender endings . ”
“ The equivalent of masculine names ending in -s shall be feminine names ending in a or -e . ”
“ From masculine names ending in -ens ... , the feminine will be formed with the ending -a , for example : PERSON – PERSON , ORG . ”

“ [ As regards names of NORP origin ] , [ CARDINAL provisions of the [ preceding ] paragraphs of this regulation shall not apply to consonants or specific groups of consonants , which are transcribed as follows :
( CARDINAL ) ’tz’ [ is transcribed by ] ‘ c’ ... ”

On DATE , in order to comply with ORG judgment of DATE , the ORG adopted a new Regulation no . CARDINAL on passports of NORP citizens and foreign permanent residents in GPE and the travel documents of stateless persons ( GPE par Latvijas pilsoņu pasēm , nepilsoņu pasēm un bezvalstnieku ceļošanas dokumentiem ) . The relevant provisions of the regulation , which came into force on DATE and replaced the aforementioned Regulation no . CARDINAL , provide :

“ In passports , the surname and forename ... of the person concerned shall be written in the form required by the law and regulations governing the spelling of surnames and forenames in the NORP language . ”

“ When the written form of the surname ... on page CARDINAL [ main page ] of the passport is different from its written form in the documents in which that name is written in its original form in another language ... , the original form ... , transliterated into the NORP alphabet , shall be entered on page CARDINAL of the passport if the person ... so wishes and is able to provide documentary evidence of [ the form concerned ] . The transliteration into the NORP alphabet shall be effected in accordance with Appendix no . CARDINAL to this regulation . ”
“ A passport shall be issued when :
( CARDINAL ) NORP the person wishes to receive a [ new ] passport to replace a valid NORP citizen ’s passport ... ”

In a judgment of DATE , ORG ( Konstitucinis teismas ) ruled on the conformity with LAW of a resolution of ORG dated DATE on the written form of forenames and surnames in the passports of citizens of GPE ir pavardžių rašymo PERSON piliečio pase ) . The relevant parts of this judgment read as follows :

“ ... LAW provides that the official language shall be NORP . The fact that the status of official language is enshrined in the LAW means that NORP has constitutional value . The official language preserves the identity of the nation , unites the civil nation , secures the expression of national sovereignty , the integrity and indivisibility of the ORG and the proper functioning of ORG institutions and local authorities . The official language is an important guarantee of equality before the law as it enables all citizens to enjoy the same relations with ORG institutions and local authorities when asserting their legitimate rights and interests . According the official language constitutional status also signifies that the legislature must ensure by law that the use of this language is protected in public life and must , in addition , afford the means for protecting the official language . Since NORP has acquired the status of official language in the LAW , it must be used in ORG institutions and local authorities and in all institutions , undertakings and organisations located on NORP territory . GPE and other legal instruments must be promulgated in the official language . Clerical , accounting , management and financial documents must be drafted in LANGUAGE . Lastly , correspondence between ORG institutions and local authorities , establishments , undertakings and organisations must be written in the official language .

Since the passport of the NORP citizen is an official document that attests to the permanent legal relationship between the individual and the ORG , namely the nationality of the person , and since the question of nationality comes within the sphere of the public life of the ORG , the individual ’s forename and surname must be written in the official language . Otherwise , the constitutional status of that language would be called into question .

As has been stated above , the sphere in which the use of the official language is obligatory is public life in GPE . Consequently , it is not obligatory in private life , in which people may use the language of their choice . The resolution of ORG does not regulate private life . It only determines how forenames and surnames are to be written in the passports of NORP citizens . ...

... It must be noted that the provisions of ORG resolution requiring a person ’s forename and surname to be written in NORP letters [ and ] as they are pronounced apply to all citizens without exception , without distinction on grounds of ethnic origin or otherwise . A person ’s membership of an ethnic group is a matter for that person to decide , that is to say that no one other than the person concerned is qualified to determine the ethnic group to which he or she belongs . Consequently , it is impossible to create exceptions enabling the official language to be used in accordance with the ethnic origin of the person concerned . Likewise , ethnic origin can not be relied upon in support of a request for exemption from the provisions that result from the language ’s status as the official language . Otherwise , the constitutional principle of the equality of everyone before the law would be infringed . ... ”

Currently , the main international instruments on the use of surnames and forenames are the conventions of ORG ) . In particular , Convention no . CARDINAL on ORG signed in GPE on CARDINAL DATE has been ratified by GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , the GPE and GPE . GPE is not a signatory to it . The relevant Articles of this convention read as follows :

“ Where a record is to be made in the civil status register by an authority of a Contracting State and there is produced for that purpose a copy of or extract from a civil status record or some other document that shows the surnames and forenames in the same characters as those used in the language in which the record is to be made , those surnames and forenames shall be reproduced literally without alteration or translation .
Any diacritic marks forming part of such surnames and forenames shall also be reproduced , even if such marks do not exist in the language in which the record is to be made . ”

“ Where a record is to be made in the civil status register by an authority of a Contracting State and there is produced for that purpose a copy of or extract from a civil status record or some other document that shows the surnames and forenames in characters other than those used in the language in which the record is to be made , those surnames and forenames shall be reproduced as far as possible by transliteration , without being translated . If there are standards recommended by ORG ( ISO ) , they shall be applied . ”

“ In the event of a discrepancy in the spelling of surnames or forenames CARDINAL of the documents produced , the person concerned shall be designated according to the civil status records or documents establishing his or her identity that were drawn up in the State of which he or she was a national at the time when they were drawn up .

For the purposes of this provision , the term ‘ national’ includes not only persons who hold the nationality of a given ORG but also refugees and stateless persons whose personal status is governed by the law of that ORG . ”
The relevant parts of the explanatory report to the convention , adopted by ORG on DATE , provide :

It is hardly necessary to emphasise the need for such uniformity . Since surnames and forenames are the main means of identifying a person , they must be consistent wherever he or she may be , and the uniformity must be reflected in all civil status records that concern him or her .

The Convention is essentially technical in nature . It is confined to prescribing that the surnames and forenames to be shown in civil status records are to be an exact reproduction of the surnames and forenames appearing in existing records or documents produced with a view to the making of a further record . ...
Article CARDINAL

Of the various systems for reproducing names , the LAW chooses the literal system ; all the letters which go to make up the surname and forenames are reproduced without modification . This system is the only one that will ensure uniformity , by avoiding , for example , the letter ‘ u’ being changed into ‘ ou’ or ‘ oe’ or the letters ‘ ORG into ‘ c’ or ‘ tch’ .

The literal reproduction rule also applies to diacritic marks . Examples are the letter ‘ ü’ with diaeresis or the letter ‘ PERSON which will be copied as ‘ PERSON and not changed into ‘ oe’ . PERSON marks must be reproduced , even if they do not exist in the language in which the record is to be made . If the record is typewritten , the diacritic marks are to be added by hand if necessary .

The first paragraph of the LAW also provides that surnames and forenames shall be reproduced without being altered or translated . However , it should be remembered that the strictness of this rule , which is especially important where particles , declined names and forenames are concerned , is tempered , in appropriate cases , by the provisions of the second , third and fourth paragraphs of LAW .
Article CARDINAL
Of the various systems of transposition , the LAW chooses transliteration : each letter , with any diacritic marks , is reproduced by its equivalent in the other language .
Where there are no standards recommended by ORG , the transposition must , as far as possible , still be achieved by transliteration .

Thus , there are at present no standards for the transliteration of NORP characters into NORP characters . Transliteration does however seem possible in many cases , especially with the help of the transliteration rules contained in ORG RCARDINAL ( international system for the transliteration of NORP characters into NORP characters ) .

On the other hand , it seems clear that in the total absence of standards it is not possible to transliterate LANGUAGE , LANGUAGE or LANGUAGE characters into NORP characters , or NORP characters into NORP or LANGUAGE characters . In these circumstances reproduction can be achieved , in the cases envisaged , by another process such as phonetic transposition . However , even in that event , translation is still forbidden . The surname and forenames must be reproduced by transliteration from the records and documents produced with a view to the making of the further record . ”
At its meeting in GPE on DATE , ORG adopted the following resolution :

“ ORG ... is of the opinion that the phrase ‘ or some other document that shows the surnames and PERSON , contained in the first paragraph of LAW , covers any public document even if it does not emanate from a civil registrar , such as a passport of the person concerned . ”

On DATE ORG ( ECJ ) delivered a judgment in PERSON v. PERSON , GPE , and PERSON , PERSON ( C-CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG Reports DATE , p. I-CARDINAL ) . In this case , which concerned a referral by ORG ( ORG ) for a preliminary ruling , the ECJ had to consider the question of the compatibility of the transliteration of a NORP name with freedom of establishment , as guaranteed by former Article CARDINAL of the LAW establishing ORG ( which became LAW when LAW came into force ) . In that case , the name of the applicant in the main proceedings , Mr PERSON ( ORG ) , a NORP national who worked as a masseur in GPE , was transcribed in a translation of his birth certificate and in the register of marriages as “ PERSON ” . This was the written form that resulted from the application of ORG CARDINAL , as prescribed by LAW no . CARDINAL ( see above ) . The ECJ ruled as follows :

“ CARDINAL . ... [ T]he national court ’s CARDINAL questions are to be regarded as seeking to ascertain , in substance , whether LAW is to be interpreted as meaning that it is contrary to that provision for the name of a NORP national who has settled in another Member ORG in order to pursue an occupation as a self - employed person to be entered in the registers of civil status of that ORG in a spelling differing from the phonetic transcription , whereby its pronunciation is modified and distorted .

CARDINAL . NORP In answering that question , it must first be borne in mind that , as the ORG has stated on numerous occasions , LAW constitutes one of the fundamental legal provisions of the Community . By prohibiting any discrimination on grounds of nationality resulting from national laws , regulations or practices , that Article seeks to ensure that , as regards the right of establishment , a Member ORG accords to nationals of other Member GPE the same treatment as it accords to its own nationals ...

CARDINAL . It must therefore be determined whether national rules relating to the transcription in NORP characters of the name of a NORP national in the registers of civil status of the Member ORG in which he is established are capable of placing him at a disadvantage in law or in fact , in comparison with the way in which a national of that Member ORG would be treated in the same circumstances .

CARDINAL . There is nothing in the LAW to preclude the transcription of a NORP name in NORP characters in the registers of civil status of a Member ORG which uses the NORP alphabet . It is therefore for the Member ORG in question to adopt legislative or administrative measures laying down the detailed rules for such transcription , in accordance with the prescriptions of any international conventions relating to civil status to which it is a party .

CARDINAL . Rules of that kind are to be regarded as incompatible with LAW only in so far as their application causes a NORP national such a degree of inconvenience as in fact to interfere with his freedom to exercise the right of establishment enshrined in that Article .

CARDINAL . Such interference occurs if a NORP national is obliged by the legislation of the ORG in which he is established to use , in the pursuit of his occupation , a spelling of his name derived from the transliteration used in the registers of civil status if that spelling is such as to modify its pronunciation and if the resulting distortion exposes him to the risk that potential clients may confuse him with other persons .

CARDINAL . It should therefore be stated in reply to the national court that LAW must be interpreted as meaning that it is contrary to that provision for a NORP national to be obliged , under the applicable national legislation , to use , in the pursuit of his occupation , a spelling of his name whereby its pronunciation is modified and the resulting distortion exposes him to the risk that potential clients may confuse him with other persons . ”
